keyTakeAways: Peru’s President José Jeri declared a 30-day state of emergency in Lima and the neighboring province of Callao to combat rising crime.
The declaration follows recent protests that resulted in one death and over 100 injuries, highlighting public frustration over security conditions.
The emergency authorizes the deployment of armed forces alongside police forces to maintain public order, signaling a shift from defensive to offensive policing strategies.

This is not the first time Peru has declared a state of emergency for security reasons; former President Dina Boluarte had done so in March 2025, though experts note such measures have not significantly reduced crime.
President Jeri, sworn in after ousting Dina Boluarte, has made tackling crime a top priority, especially in the face of protests led by Generation Z youth demanding action.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Peru’s new president, José Jeri, declared a 30-day state of emergency in Lima and the neighboring province of Callao to combat rising crime, following violent protests that left one person dead and over 100 injured. The emergency allows for the deployment of armed forces and police to restore public order, marking a shift from defensive to offensive tactics in law enforcement. This move follows previous emergency declarations under former President Dina Boluarte, though experts have questioned their long-term effectiveness. The protests were largely driven by youth from Generation Z, highlighting public demand for meaningful action on security issues.
title: Peru declares 30-day state of emergency in Lima to tackle rising crime
